This wasn't a flame thrower, it was a huge blowtorch. A blowtorch spits gas a short distance because of the weight of gas, then it gets ignited, a flamethrower spits liquid that can go up to 100 feet before combusting completely, due to its weight and density. Flamethrowers also usually have a binding agents in the fuel as well, so that the liquid doesn't just combust in the air, but sticks on the target as well. There's a reason anyone can buy Elon Musks "not a flamethrower" but you need a license to get an actual flamethower.

If I have a bit of aluminum foil on something I'm baking in a 400 degree (F) oven, once I pull it out I can immediately pull off this 400 degree sheet of metal and crumple it in my fist without being burned. That thin sheet of aerogel will conduct heat at such a slow rate that our hand will make the upper surface much more colder than the lower surface of the aerogel sheet
And because it'll take so long for the heat to get transferred from the lower surface of the sheet to the upper surface, we can place our hands on the sheet
In simple words, the sheet colds down as soon as our hands touches the sheet

The flamethrower is probably not broken. Large scale flame effects release gas from the tank quickly, causing it to cool. On a very small tank like that doesn't take much. As it cools, the liquid propane remaining can't decompress as quickly, giving less effect, but still continuing to cool the tank until it completely locks up.

What you should have used was a larger standard grill propane tank, and a simple roofing torch wand with a hose. That novelty flame thrower with a small propane tank froze up due to rapid pressure reduction inside the small tank. That is why propane can be used as a refrigerant, except it is not, only because its explosive. But there was no damage done to the flame thrower, so no need to apologize. Try a warmer day or placing the propane tank in room temperature water. No not hot water, because heat transfers better to something within a similar temerature range.

There is only yellow and orange flames. There is no blue flame the hottest. Your BS. The hottest fires are from oxyacetylene torches (about 3000 degrees Centigrade) that combine oxygen and gas to create pinpoint blue flames. Color also tells us about the temperature of a candle flame. The inner core of the candle flame is light blue, with a temperature of around 1800 K. Propane has the hottest part of the flame as blue. It is a more efficient combustion. On the other hand, flame with a less efficient combustion will go from white at the hottest to yellow to orange to red.

Perfect demonstration of the fact that humans don't usually detect temperature, we detect thermal flux.

When you touch something and it's hot, you're not measuring its temperature, you're measuring how fast heat is able to move into your skin. That's just usually strongly correlated with temperature, and the more important factor.


There are specific temperature sensitive proteins that change shape only at certain temperatures, and those do measure absolute values to maintain homeostasis, but the external sensation of heat is thermal flux.

By the way the fact that you can put your hand on hot/cold aerogel is because of its low effusivity. That's a number that characterises the "felt" temperature at the interface of that material with another material, and increases with the square root of density. This is why you don't feel like a 17° polystyrene or wood object is cold but an iron one is. Same with aerogel
More info here:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermal_effusivity

This is why you can pull a hot loaf of bread out of the oven and touch it soon after. Touch the metal pan and the heat is going to burn you... but bread is worse at transferring heat. Touch it and you won't burn as fast, or at all. Since it loses heat slower to the surroundings, it's actually hotter than the pan, but the pan feels hotter and burns you quicker because what your body is measuring isn't heat - but rather heat transfer and heat differentials.


Same reason you can slow-cook a frog, or burn yourself unintentionally and slowly if you gradually run out of cold water from a hot/cold tap.

Different materials have different "emissivity" in the IR, and the IR thermometer (and FLIR) need to be set to a specific value. The low conductivity -- the demo where he can touch the hot surface -- makes me think that the e-value of the material may also be extreme. For the blanket, he specifically said that it has Iron added to lower its ability to radiate!


The temperature of the coating and the uncoated square might actually be the same, when you measured 60 degree difference with the IR thermometer. The IR thermometer needs to be calibrated against a surface-contact thermometer; in fact many devices like that have a jack for a thermocouple.


The second demo (with the coated plate) also teaches something that should be applied to the first demo as well: He was touching the blanket and it "was not very hot". In reality, it could be much hotter but simply not transfer heat to his skin.

I work in energy efficienyfor buildings in Germany. Building permits often dictate the outer border of a building. At the same time you need to insulate to a certain degree. If you can make the outer wall thinner by making the insulation thinner, you create more area inside. Area equals the buildings worth.
Assume you build a house and want to sell to an investor (common practice). It has an outside perimeter of 40x15m => 110 m and you have 5 levels. And assume you build with 3 cm aerogel instead of 10 cm regular insulation. (110 x 0.07) x 5 levels = 38.5 m². A square meter would sell for 3,000 €. You would sell your building for 115,500 € more than before. I really hope they can produce this cheap.

The boring not-a-flamethrower has a design flaw in that it uses a top mounted liquefied propane gas cylinder. This means that during extended operation the regulator valve can and will ice up as it is being exposed to liquid propane that is undergoing a phase change to gas, and absorbing a lot of heat in the process.
This can permanently damage the regulator valve, but in most cases after several hours (or a few days in cold weather) the valve should thaw and start working again.

You need a bit of knowledge in heat transfer to really understand what's happening.

So I think I can clarify that for those who are still wondering.
Insulating materials have two properties taken into consideration when evaluating their thermal insulation quality.
Thermal Conductivity [W/m.K] and Thermal Capacity [W/m^3.K or the more usual W/kg.K]. Absortivity and Emissivity are also important (It's what the thermal camera turns into Temperature), much like convective index, but we'll only be talking about the material itself, not what happens on the boundary. There's also Thermal diffusivity, which is how heat distributes itself in the material from a gradient of temperature, but let's keep it basic.

What happens in the macro scale is that the aerogel has a very low thermal conductivity and what seems to be an also very low thermal capacity. The low conductivity DELAYS the increase in temperature in one side and the low thermal capacity is what allows that side to retain little thermal energy when touched. So that's why Derek can touch a 100C+ surface withouth burning himself. His body is much more conductive than the aerogel, so what happens is that when he touches the plate, his body quickly conducts away the little thermal energy in the aerogel face, effectively cooling it down. The low thermal conductivity of the Aerogel ensures that little heat is transfered through it.
Derek is effectivelly acting as a heat sink.

So, here's some temperature perspective for us U.S. folks:
100 degrees C = 212 degrees F

200 degrees C = 392 degrees F
400 degrees C = 753 degrees F
600 degrees C = 1,112 degrees F
800 degrees C = 1,472 degrees F
1,000 degrees C = 1,832 degrees F
1,500 degrees C = 2,732 degrees F
2,000 degrees C = 3,632 degrees F
